facts.text: Civil Appeal No. 80 of 1963 filed in Supreme Court.

anchor.surface_text: CIVIL APPELLATE JURISDICTION Civil Appeal NO. 80 of 1963.

facts.text: Appeal from judgment and order dated April 4, 1962 of Punjab High Court in Civil Writ No. 961 of 1961.

anchor.surface_text: Appeal from the judgment and order dated April 4, 1962, of the Punjab High Court in Civil Writ No. 961 of 1961.

facts.text: Appellant appeared in person before Supreme Court.

anchor.surface_text: The appellant appeared in person. K. Daphtary, Attorney General, Mohinder Singh Punnu, Deputy Advocate-General, Punjab

facts.text: Judgment delivered on September 2, 1963 by N. Rajagopala Ayyangar J.

anchor.surface_text: September 2, 1963. The judgment of S. K. Das, K. Subba Rao and N. Rajagopala Ayyangar, JJ., was delivered by N. Rajagopala Ayyangar, JJ.

facts.text: Appellant was Civil Surgeon employed by State Government.

anchor.surface_text: The appellant was a Civil Surgeon in the employment of the State Government who had been granted leave preparatory to retirement,

facts.text: Government revoked appellant's leave preparatory to retirement in June 1961.

anchor.surface_text: and subsequently, in June 1961, orders were passed by Government 1 revoking the leave he had originally been granted and recalling him to duty,

facts.text: Government placed appellant under suspension pending inquiry into charges of misconduct in June 1961.

anchor.surface_text: 2 simultaneously placing him under suspension pending the result of an inquiry into certain charges of misconduct, and 3 ordering a departmental inquiry against him.

facts.text: Appellant filed petition under Art. 226 in Punjab High Court challenging orders.

anchor.surface_text: The legality of these orders was challenged by the appellant in the petition that he filed in the High Court.

facts.text: Punjab High Court dismissed the writ petition.

anchor.surface_text: The petition was dismissed by the learned Judges, but on application by the appellant,

facts.text: High Court granted certificate under Art. 133(1)(c) for appeal to Supreme Court.

anchor.surface_text: he was granted a certificate of fitness on the strength of which he has filed the present appeal.

facts.text: Appellant applied for leave preparatory to retirement reaching age 55 on June 15, 1961.

anchor.surface_text: He was reaching the age of 55 on June 15, 1961 and he applied for leave until that period. His leave was sanctioned

facts.text: Leave sanctioned effective December 18, 1960, gazetted January 27, 1961.

anchor.surface_text: His leave was sanctioned with effect from December 18, 1960 and this was gazetted on January 27, 1961.

facts.text: Impugned orders issued on June 3, 1961 revoking leave and suspending appellant.

anchor.surface_text: It is this leave that was revoked by the impugned orders on June 3, 1961 and under these the appellant was placed under suspension

facts.text: Departmental inquiry ordered against appellant on June 29, 1961.

anchor.surface_text: and the order dated June 29, 1961 directing an inquiry into the charges against him.

facts.text: Chief Minister requested appellant to perform operation on his son Surinder Singh in April 1960.

anchor.surface_text: The appellant was requested by the Chief Minister to perform an operation on his son--Surinder Singh-in April 1960.

facts.text: Appellant performed operation on Surinder Singh.

anchor.surface_text: The operation was performed.

facts.text: Surinder Singh left appellant's care prematurely, angering Chief Minister.

anchor.surface_text: Surinder, however, left the appellants place and the Chief Minister became angry for the supposed negligence of the appellant

facts.text: Tape-recorded conversations corroborate operation on Surinder Singh.

anchor.surface_text: From the internal evidence furnished by this tape-record itself it is seen that this talk was on May 1, 1960.

facts.text: Appellant supplied medicines to Chief Minister's wife from hospital stores or personally bought.

anchor.surface_text: The Chief Ministers wife had been asking for medicines to be sent to her by the appellant for the use of herself,

facts.text: Appellant supplied Singer sewing machines to Mrs. Kairon.

anchor.surface_text: the supply of two Singer Sewing machines to Mrs. Kairon.

facts.text: Kirpa Singh stayed at appellant's house for 7 months at instance of Chief Minister.

anchor.surface_text: One Kirpa Singh was working as the manager of an automobile concern known as National Motors, Jullundur which was either directly or indirectly owned by Surinder-the son of the Chief Minister.

facts.text: Appellant evicted Kirpa Singh in April 1960, irritating Chief Minister.

anchor.surface_text: but in or about April, 1960 the appellant desired Kirpa Singh to look out for a lodging and board elsewhere and the latter had to do so. This was a further cause of irritation

facts.text: Article against Chief Minister published in Blitz weekly on January 15, 1961.

anchor.surface_text: in the issue of the Weekly newspaper Blitz dated the 15th January, 1961 there appeared an article in which allegations were made against the Chief Minister.

facts.text: Appellant's wife wrote to Blitz confirming allegations in March 1961.

anchor.surface_text: On March 18, 1961 the appellants wife wrote a letter to the Blitz confirming the allegations against the Chief Minister

facts.text: Supreme Court held orders vitiated by mala fides of Chief Minister.

anchor.surface_text: We therefore hold that the impunged orders were vitiated by mala fides, in that they were motivated by an improper purpose
dismissing a petition filed by the appellant in that Court under Art. 226 of the Constitution and has been preferred pursuant

issues.text: Whether every one of the impugned orders of June 1961 (a) recalling him from the leave previously granted, (b) placing him under suspension pending an inquiry, and (c) starting an inquiry against him were illegal for the reason that such action on the part of Government was contrary to and not permitted by the relevant Service Rules applicable to him

anchor.surface_text: The second ground of challenge was that these orders, assuming them to be within the power of Government on a proper interpretation of the rules were passed mala fide, by or at the instance of the Chief Minister, Punjab, who was personally hostile to him by

issues.text: Whether leave, once sanctioned, cannot be revoked after the officer has proceeded on leave

anchor.surface_text: It is contended that leave, once sanctioned, cannot be revoked after the officer has proceeded on leave. He can only be recalled to duty.

issues.text: Whether a Government servant on leave preparatory to retirement cannot be suspended as suspension means a persons ceasing to work

anchor.surface_text: This contention, again, has no force. A Government servant on leave preparatory to retirement cannot be suspended as suspension means a persons ceasing to work on the post he holds

issues.text: Whether the order revoking the leave must precede the order of suspension

anchor.surface_text: Another contention is that the order revoking the leave must precede the order of suspension, and as the order of suspension was before the revocation of his leave it is bad.

issues.text: Whether these orders of June 3 were actually communicated to the appellant after the date of his retirement and is therefore ineffective

anchor.surface_text: The next contention is that these orders of June 3 were actually communicated to the appellant after the date of his retirement and is therefore ineffective.

issues.text: Whether the rules governing his service did not empower the Governor to pass the impugned orders

anchor.surface_text: The appellant has questioned the correctness of the impugned orders, broadly speaking, on two grounds. One is that the rules governing his service did not empower the Governor

anchor.surface_text: The second is that the impugned orders were passed mala fide as the Chief Minister, who was in charge of the department of Health, bore ill-will towards him.

holdings.text: Impugned orders not beyond the power of the Government under relevant service rules

anchor.surface_text: The appellant has questioned the correctness of the impugned orders, broadly speaking, on two grounds. One is that the rules governing his service did not empower the Governor

holdings.reasoning_summary: Agrees with Dayal J.'s analysis of PCSR 8.15, 3.26(d), PCS Punishment R7 empowering revocation of leave, suspension, and inquiry even post-proceeding on leave and pre-retirement

holdings.text: Provision in Art. 310 does not confer power to compel service post-superannuation apart from service rules

anchor.surface_text: Besides, we should not be taken to have acceded to the submission of the learned Attorney-General who appeared for the respondent-State, that the provision in Art. 310 1  of the Constitution that members of a Civil Service

holdings.reasoning_summary: Contrary to State of Bihar v. Abdul Majid; unwarranted construction of 'pleasure of Governor'

holdings.text: Impugned orders vitiated by mala fides of Chief Minister motivated by improper purpose of vengeance

anchor.surface_text: We therefore hold that the impunged orders were vitiated by mala fides, in that they were motivated by an improper purpose

holdings.reasoning_summary: Tape records, documents, Blitz article, absence of denial by CM prove dominant improper motive outside statutory purpose of ensuring service probity; ultra vires and abuse of power

holdings.text: Leave preparatory to retirement can be revoked even after officer proceeded on leave when exigencies require

anchor.surface_text: It is contended that leave, once sanctioned, cannot be revoked after the officer has proceeded on leave. He can only be recalled to duty.

holdings.reasoning_summary: PCSR 8.15 reserves discretion to revoke anytime; no time restriction; revocation distinct from recall

holdings.text: Government servant on leave preparatory to retirement holds lien on post and can be suspended

anchor.surface_text: This contention, again, has no force. A Government servant on leave preparatory to retirement cannot be suspended as suspension means a persons ceasing to work on the post he holds

holdings.reasoning_summary: Suspension prevents work during period; effective even on leave; lien subsists per r.3.13

holdings.text: Sequence of issuance of revocation and suspension orders does not affect validity if power exists

anchor.surface_text: Another contention is that the order revoking the leave must precede the order of suspension, and as the order of suspension was before the revocation of his leave it is bad.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Orders issued same day; sequence immaterial to substantive power

holdings.text: Impugned orders effective from issuance date June 3, 1961, despite delayed communication post-retirement date

anchor.surface_text: The next contention is that these orders of June 3 were actually communicated to the appellant after the date of his retirement and is therefore ineffective.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Gazetted June 10; effective on issuance for servant on leave; communication delay immaterial

holdings.text: Tape-recorded conversations admissible and genuine corroborating allegations against Chief Minister

anchor.surface_text: From the internal evidence furnished by this tape-record itself it is seen that this talk was on May 1, 1960.

holdings.reasoning_summary: No tampering shown; State had opportunity to verify copies; no denial of voices; weight not admissibility affected

holdings.text: Power to revoke leave, suspend, inquire conditioned on bona fide use for service probity; vitiated if dominant purpose improper

anchor.surface_text: The Service Rules which are statutory vest the power to pass the impugned orders on the Govern- ment. The expression Government in the context is the functionary within the State who is vested with executive power in the relevant field.

precedents.cited_proposition: statutory power to compulsorily acquire land cannot be exercised for purposes other than specified
precedents.cited_holding: A body such as the Municipal Council of Sydney, authorised to take land compulsorily for specified purposes, will not be permitted to exercise its powers for different purposes

anchor.surface_text: We therefore allow the appeal and set aside the order dated June 3, 1961 revoking the leave granted and placing the appellant under suspension and the order dated June 29, 1961 directing an inquiry into the charges against him. As the appellant has failed to make out the other point about the orders being contrary to the Service Rules we di

outcome.relief_summary: Appeal allowed; orders dated June 3, 1961 (revocation of leave and suspension) and June 29, 1961 (departmental inquiry) set aside
directions: No order as to costs here and in the High Court
